title-group.article-title: Estimating the Systematic Risk of an Industry Segment: A Mathematical Programming Approach

abstract.p: Financial theory specifies that a capital budgeting proposal should earn a required rate of return that is commensurate with the risk and debt capacity of the proposal itself. In general, the firm's cost of capital would be an inappropriate criterion for all proposals arising in the firm, since a project's risk need not be the same as that of the firm. In practice, however, there is evidence that surprisingly few firms estimate specific required rates for individual proposals, thus the tacit assumption is made that the project's risk is not vastly dissimilar to the firm's. Those that do wish to make the requisite adjustments are hampered by the lack of a clear procedure for doing so. A firm with publicly traded securities that has risk characteristics directly analogous to the project is usually impossible to find. This lack of readily available market information compels the analyst to resort to indirect methods for estimating systematic risk. Unfortunately, such methods lack strong theoretical support. The authors of this paper develop and apply a mathematical programming formulation that shows promise in estimating the systematic risk (Beta) coefficients for industry segments. Knowledge of these coefficients enables the analyst to construct required rates of return for capital budgeting proposals that involve operations in any individual industry segment or any collection of segments.
